title: NIH asks health professionals to remain vigilant on suspected Diphtheria cases
content:
ISLAMABAD, Jan 12 (APP): The National Institute of Health (NIH) on Thursday alerted the health professionals to remain vigilant for picking up suspected Corynebacterium Diphtheria cases and to undertake prevention and control measures during the current winter season.
According to the advisory issued by the NIH’s Center for Disease Control for Prevention and treatment of Corynebacterium Diphtheria, sporadic cases of Diphtheria usually surfaced in Pakistan from November to February, and in the year of 2022, some 26 laboratory confirmed cases reported from all across the country.
It said that the Diphtheria was a potentially life-threatening bacterial disease caused by infection with toxin producing strains of Corynebacterium Diphtheriae. It was transmitted usually from person-to-person through respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing.
While informing about the probable cases, the advisory said,”Any person who meets the clinical case definition for respiratory diphtheria like upper respiratory tract illness characterized by laryngitis or pharyngitis or tonsillitis and a visible adherent membrane on the tonsils, pharynx or nose and without epidemiological linkage and laboratory confirmation.”
It added that any confirmed case was a probable case that had been laboratory confirmed or linked epidemiologically to a laboratory confirmed case. Persons with positive Corynebacterium Diphtheriae culture, but asymptomatic, should not be reported as suspected or confirmed cases.
The advisory said Diphtheria transmitted from person to person, skin lesions usually through respiratory droplets (coughing or sneezing). The infection might come in contact or touching open sores (skin lesions) and material objects (toys or clothes) used by the person who already was sick with diphtheria.
“The incubation period is usually 2-5 days, occasionally longer while the bacteriological culture and PCR can be used to detect toxigenic strains of C Diphtheria which is a standard test for confirmation specimen collection.”
It said that persons should immediately start the treatment if Diphtheria were suspected without waiting for laboratory confirmation. It added Diphtheria patients were usually kept in isolation untiI they were no longer able to infect others.
